member.name: T:SmartFormat.Core.Extensions.IFormatter
member.summary: Converts an object to a string.

member.name: P:SmartFormat.Core.Extensions.IFormatter.Names
member.summary:
An extension can be explicitly called by using any of its names.
Any extensions with "" names will be called implicitly (when no named formatter is specified).
For example, "{0:default:N2}" or "{0:d:N2}" will explicitly call the "default" extension. "{0:N2}" will implicitly call the "default" extension (and other extensions, too).

member.name: M:SmartFormat.Core.Extensions.IFormatter.TryEvaluateFormat(SmartFormat.Core.Extensions.IFormattingInfo)
member.summary:
Writes the current value to the output, using the specified format.
IF this extension cannot write the value, returns false, otherwise true.

member.name: T:SmartFormat.Core.Extensions.IFormattingInfo
member.summary: Contains all necessary info for formatting a value
member.example: In "{Items.Length:choose(1,2,3):one|two|three}", the would be the value of "Items.Length", the would be "1,2,3", and the would be "one|two|three".

member.name: P:SmartFormat.Core.Extensions.IFormattingInfo.CurrentValue
member.summary: The current value that is to be formatted.

member.name: P:SmartFormat.Core.Extensions.IFormattingInfo.Format
member.summary: This format specifies how to output the .

member.name: P:SmartFormat.Core.Extensions.IFormattingInfo.Placeholder
member.summary: Contains all the details about the current placeholder.

member.name: P:SmartFormat.Core.Extensions.IFormattingInfo.Alignment
member.summary:
Alignment inserts spaces into the output to ensure consistent length.
Positive numbers insert spaces to the left, to right-align the text. Negative numbers insert spaces to the right, to left-align the text.
This should only work with the Default Formatter, but is optional with custom formatters.
This is primarily for compatibility with String.Format.

member.name: P:SmartFormat.Core.Extensions.IFormattingInfo.FormatterOptions
member.summary:
When a named formatter is used, this will hold the options.
For example, in "{0:choose(1,2,3):one|two|three}", FormatterOptions is "1,2,3".

member.summary: Parses a format string.

member.name: F:SmartFormat.Core.Parsing.Parser.alphanumericSelectors
member.summary: If false, only digits are allowed as selectors. If true, selectors can be alpha-numeric. This allows optimized alpha-character detection. Specify any additional selector chars in AllowedSelectorChars.

member.name: F:SmartFormat.Core.Parsing.Parser.allowedSelectorChars
member.summary: A list of allowable selector characters, to support additional selector syntaxes such as math. Digits are always included, and letters can be included with AlphanumericSelectors.

member.name: F:SmartFormat.Core.Parsing.Parser.operators
member.summary: A list of characters that come between selectors. This can be "." for dot-notation, "[]" for arrays, or even math symbols. By default, there are no operators.

member.name: F:SmartFormat.Core.Parsing.Parser.alternativeEscaping
member.summary: If false, double-curly braces are escaped. If true, the AlternativeEscapeChar is used for escaping braces.

member.name: F:SmartFormat.Core.Parsing.Parser.alternativeEscapeChar
member.summary: If AlternativeEscaping is true, then this character is used to escape curly braces.

member.name: M:SmartFormat.Core.Parsing.Parser.AddAlphanumericSelectors
member.summary: Includes a-z and A-Z in the list of allowed selector chars.

member.name: M:SmartFormat.Core.Parsing.Parser.AddAdditionalSelectorChars(System.String)
member.summary: Adds specific characters to the allowed selector chars.

member.name: M:SmartFormat.Core.Parsing.Parser.AddOperators(System.String)
member.summary: Adds specific characters to the allowed operator chars. An operator is a character that is in the selector string that splits the selectors.

member.name: M:SmartFormat.Core.Parsing.Parser.UseAlternativeEscapeChar(System.Char)
member.summary: Sets the AlternativeEscaping option to True so that braces will only be escaped after the specified character.

member.name: M:SmartFormat.Core.Parsing.Parser.UseBraceEscaping
member.summary: [Default] Uses {{ and }} for escaping braces for compatibility with String.Format. However, this does not work very well with nested placeholders, so it is recommended to use an alternative escape char.

member.name: T:SmartFormat.Core.Parsing.Placeholder

member.example: For example, in "{Items.Length,10:choose(1,2,3):one|two|three}", the s is "10", the s are "Items" and "Length", the is "choose", the is "1,2,3", and the is "one|two|three".

member.summary: Includes an issue message in the output

member.name: F:SmartFormat.Core.Settings.ErrorAction.Ignore

member.name: F:SmartFormat.Core.Settings.ErrorAction.MaintainTokens
member.summary: Leaves invalid tokens unmodified in the text.

member.name: P:SmartFormat.Core.Settings.SmartSettings.CaseSensitivity

member.name: M:SmartFormat.Extensions.ConditionalFormatter.TryEvaluateCondition(SmartFormat.Core.Parsing.Format,System.Decimal,System.Boolean@,SmartFormat.Core.Parsing.Format@)
member.summary:
Evaluates a conditional format.
Each condition must start with a comparor: ">/>=", "</<=", "=", "!=". Conditions must be separated by either "&" (AND) or "/" (OR). The conditional statement must end with a "?".
Examples: >=21&<30&!=25/=40?

member.name: T:SmartFormat.Extensions.DefaultFormatter
member.summary: Do the default formatting, same logic as "String.Format".

member.name: M:SmartFormat.Extensions.DefaultSource.TryEvaluateSelector(SmartFormat.Core.Extensions.ISelectorInfo)
member.summary: Performs the default index-based selector, same as String.Format.

member.name: T:SmartFormat.Extensions.ListFormatter
member.summary:
If the source value is an array (or supports ICollection), then each item will be custom formatted.
Syntax: #1: "format|spacer" #2: "format|spacer|last spacer" #3: "format|spacer|last spacer|two spacer"
The format will be used for each item in the collection, the spacer will be between all items, and the last spacer will replace the spacer for the last item only.
Example: CustomFormat("{Dates:D|; |; and }", {#1/1/2000#, #12/31/2999#, #9/9/9999#}) = "January 1, 2000; December 31, 2999; and September 9, 9999" In this example, format = "D", spacer = "; ", and last spacer = "; and "
Advanced: Composite Formatting is allowed in the format by using nested braces. If a nested item is detected, Composite formatting will be used.
Example: CustomFormat("{Sizes:{Width}x{Height}|, }", {new Size(4,3), new Size(16,9)}) = "4x3, 16x9" In this example, format = "{Width}x{Height}". Notice the nested braces.

member.name: M:SmartFormat.Extensions.ListFormatter.TryEvaluateSelector(SmartFormat.Core.Extensions.ISelectorInfo)
member.summary:
This allows an integer to be used as a selector to index an array (or list).
This is better described using an example: CustomFormat("{Dates.2.Year}", {#1/1/2000#, #12/31/2999#, #9/9/9999#}) = "9999" The ".2" selector is used to reference Dates[2].

member.name: F:SmartFormat.Extensions.ListFormatter._collectionIndex
member.remarks: Wrap, so that CollectionIndex can be used without code changes.

member.name: P:SmartFormat.Extensions.ListFormatter.CollectionIndex
member.remarks: System.Runtime.Remoting.Messaging and CallContext.Logical[Get|Set]Data not supported by .Net Core. Instead .Net Core provides AsyncLocal<T> Good examples are: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn906268(v=vs.110).aspx and https://github.com/StephenCleary/AsyncLocal/blob/master/src/UnitTests/UnitTests.cs

member.name: T:SmartFormat.Utilities.PluralRules.PluralRuleDelegate
member.summary:
This delegate determines which singular or plural word should be chosen for the given quantity.
This allows each language to define its own behavior for singular or plural words.
It should return the index of the correct parameter.
member.param: The value that is being referenced by the singular or plural words

member.param: The language code in two-letter ISO-639 format.
member.remarks: The pluralization rules are taken from .

member.summary: Returns True if the value is inclusively between the min and max and has no fraction.

member.name: P:SmartFormat.Utilities.TimeSpanUtility.DefaultFormatOptions
member.summary: These are the default options that will be used when no option is specified.

member.name: P:SmartFormat.Utilities.TimeSpanUtility.AbsoluteDefaults
member.summary: These are the absolute default options that will be used as a safeguard, just in case DefaultFormatOptions is missing a value.

member.name: M:SmartFormat.Utilities.TimeSpanUtility.ToTimeString(System.TimeSpan,SmartFormat.Utilities.TimeSpanFormatOptions,SmartFormat.Utilities.TimeTextInfo)

summary.para: Turns a TimeSpan into a human-readable text.
Uses the specified timeSpanFormatOptions.
For example: "31.23:59:00.555" = "31 days 23 hours 59 minutes 0 seconds 555 milliseconds"

param.name: options
param.para: A combination of flags that determine the formatting options.
These will be combined with the default timeSpanFormatOptions.

member.param: An object that supplies the text to use for output

member.name: M:SmartFormat.Utilities.TimeSpanUtility.Floor(System.TimeSpan,System.Int64)

summary.para: Returns the largest TimeSpan less than or equal to the specified interval.
For example: Floor("00:57:00", TimeSpan.TicksPerMinute * 5) => "00:55:00"

member.param: A TimeSpan to be rounded.
Specifies the interval for rounding. Use TimeSpan.TicksPer____.

member.name: M:SmartFormat.Utilities.TimeSpanUtility.Ceiling(System.TimeSpan,System.Int64)

summary.para: Returns the smallest TimeSpan greater than or equal to the specified interval.
For example: Ceiling("00:57:00", TimeSpan.TicksPerMinute * 5) => "01:00:00"

member.param: A TimeSpan to be rounded.
Specifies the interval for rounding. Use TimeSpan.TicksPer____.

member.name: M:SmartFormat.Utilities.TimeSpanUtility.Round(System.TimeSpan,System.Int64)

summary.para: Returns the TimeSpan closest to the specified interval.
For example: Round("00:57:00", TimeSpan.TicksPerMinute * 5) => "00:55:00"

member.param: A TimeSpan to be rounded.
Specifies the interval for rounding. Use TimeSpan.TicksPer____.

summary.para: Determines all options for time formatting.
This one value actually contains 4 settings:
Abbreviate / AbbreviateOff
LessThan / LessThanOff
Truncate Auto / Shortest / Fill / Full
Range MilliSeconds / Seconds / Minutes / Hours / Days / Weeks (Min / Max)

member.name: F:SmartFormat.Utilities.TimeSpanFormatOptions.InheritDefaults
member.summary: Specifies that all timeSpanFormatOptions should be inherited from TimeSpanUtility.DefaultTimeFormatOptions.

member.name: F:SmartFormat.Utilities.TimeSpanFormatOptions.Abbreviate
member.summary: Abbreviates units. Example: "1d 2h 3m 4s 5ms"

member.name: F:SmartFormat.Utilities.TimeSpanFormatOptions.AbbreviateOff
member.summary: Does not abbreviate units. Example: "1 day 2 hours 3 minutes 4 seconds 5 milliseconds"

member.name: F:SmartFormat.Utilities.TimeSpanFormatOptions.LessThan
member.summary: Displays "less than 1 (unit)" when the TimeSpan is smaller than the minimum range.

member.name: F:SmartFormat.Utilities.TimeSpanFormatOptions.LessThanOff
member.summary: Displays "0 (units)" when the TimeSpan is smaller than the minimum range.

summary.para: Displays the highest non-zero value within the range.
Displays all non-zero values within the range.
Example: "00.23:00:59.000" = "23 hours 59 minutes"
Displays the highest non-zero value and all lesser values within the range.
Example: "00.23:00:59.000" = "23 hours 0 minutes 59 seconds 0 milliseconds"
Displays all values within the range.
Example: "00.23:00:59.000" = "0 days 23 hours 0 minutes 59 seconds 0 milliseconds"
Determines the range of units to display.
You may combine two values to form the minimum and maximum for the range.
Example: (RangeMinutes) defines a range of Minutes only; (RangeHours | RangeSeconds) defines a range of Hours to Seconds.
Determines the range of units to display.
You may combine two values to form the minimum and maximum for the range.
Example: (RangeMinutes) defines a range of Minutes only; (RangeHours | RangeSeconds) defines a range of Hours to Seconds.
Determines the range of units to display.
You may combine two values to form the minimum and maximum for the range.
Example: (RangeMinutes) defines a range of Minutes only; (RangeHours | RangeSeconds) defines a range of Hours to Seconds.
Determines the range of units to display.
You may combine two values to form the minimum and maximum for the range.
Example: (RangeMinutes) defines a range of Minutes only; (RangeHours | RangeSeconds) defines a range of Hours to Seconds.
